text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Tony
ballina record distant dismissed
Tony Molina is a California
singer-songwriter who is following up a
seven and she dropped on Matador Records
a little while back as well as the
embarrassing times EP he has also put in
time as a vocalist and a guitar player
for the punk band of ins a band whose
sound is loud it's lo-fi it's poppy it's
sweet its melodic its energetic a lot of
these same characteristics carry on into
Tony's music as well the dude has an
addiction to power pop groups like
Weezer and underground or indie rock
from the 90s like that is her junior or
Elliott Smith heat miser Seba dough plus
a lot of the songs that Tony writes and
records are vibrantly colored with
harmonized super harmonized guitar solos
that occasionally show off a classical
music influence as well so you know
there's definitely some Fitness
underneath all that grime on Tony's
records and the songs that this guy
brings to the table on his LPS on this
record are a mix of ballads very pretty
interludes and sort of stone-faced power
pop rockers all of which are packaged
into super short song lengths typically
landing somewhere in the thirty second
to one minute mark
now this LP that we're talking about in
this video was put out late last year
was a bit of an underground release when
under the radar this year Slumberland
records is reissuing it it's 12 songs
the album itself runs just under 12
minutes and every single one of these
tracks are boiled down to their most
basic of elements there might be a
catchy riff or a vocal melody starting
off the track and then there's a verse
and maybe if you're lucky the song ends
off with a spectacular melodic guitar
solo but Tony's ultra simplified
approach doesn't necessarily mean that
there is a lack of effort on these songs
I mean there is an immediate sweetness
to nearly all the songs here and the
guitar solos are just really fun
so not only on a level is the
instrumentation on this thing impressive
but this is a bit of a concept record a
break up record so many songs on this LP
about heartbreak the end of a
relationship moving on past that initial
breakup point Tony sings about missing
this person going crazy being around
this person having been in a
relationship where this person would
would build him up just to tear him down
and even though Tony's lyrical approach
on this LP can be pretty basic at times
every once in a while lyric will stick
out that's like huh like the glass is
only being filled for the chance to have
it spilled Oh despite all the depressing
breakup imagery it is a fun little album
and an LP whose pacing is so fast these
songs start and so quickly that I mean
it's it's hard not to repeat the album
the album is over and done with and
starting right back at the beginning
before I even know it and the beginning
doesn't sound too much unlike the ending
you know at least when you're first
listening to the record so it's kind of
like to me this album is the musical
equivalent to a Jif a gift
a guy a guy but it's not just how fast
these songs start and end it's how
quickly they surrender their sweetest
moments like a cheap one-night stand
that gives this record an incomparable
amount of replayability I will try to go
into the songs themselves a little bit
but they are so freakin brief all the
guitar riffs are fairly catchy and
straightforward they have a really
crunchy tone to them the bass the drums
are hidden away in the background the
vocals seemed overdubbed for a nice very
layered effect that makes them kind of
pop out it's a rough recording but the
songs shine through even with the sort
of apathetic indie rock vocals that are
layered on top of this thing I love the
vocal melody on the track nowhere to go
the song can't believe has one of my
favorite chord progressions on this
entire LP wandering boy poet is a really
nice acoustic ballad on this thing
nothing I can do is this really slow
heavy distorted monolithic in comparison
to the other songs on here slow burner
the
sick-ass roof is really nice pretty
acoustic intro
sick-ass riff tony's got a sense of

because it has just this genuine feeling
of over you girl this is over not only

awesome set of chugging guitar riffs on

the ending song has a really pretty

to me while this record really where's

really highlights the power of the short

short songs are great they don't repeat

who wants a minutes worth of ideas

really love that refrain and you wanna
